newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa's Gengold says gold price drop not worrying.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa's Gengold says gold price drop not worrying.

text.p: Gencor Ltd's gold division Gengold said on Wednesday the recent fall in the gold price to an 18-month low was not worrying because it represented the bottom end of a long term trading range.
"The percentage decline of around two percent excites a lot of comment, but its real influence is on market sentiment," Gengold managing director Tom Dale told Reuters.
Gold was fixed on Tuesday in London at the lowest level since March 6, 1995. The precious metal was fixed at $378.65 in the afternoon and $377.05 in the morning.
On Wednesday, gold edged higher with the morning fix at $379.20 an ounce.
Dale said the move in the gold price represented less than one percentage point.
"The movement is really a storm in a teacup, it excites a lot of comment, but how far does it move in percentage terms, a quarter of a percent or something.

"It has been trading in a range between $375 and $400 since 1993. The fact that it is at the bottom of that range, I don't think should cause a great deal of excitement," he said in a telephone interview.
Dale said strong physical fabrication demand underpins the present level, adding another major factor affecting sentiment was continuing talk of International Monetary Fund gold sales.
The IMF planned to sell about five percent, or five million ounces of its gold reserve to finance increased aid to poor nations.
IMF Interim Committee Chairman Phillipe Maystadt said in Washington on Tuesday the world body would know sometime next year whether it will need to sell gold to finance aid.

"There is obviously negative sentiment being caused by the talk about IMF sales of gold and I think the thing that puts a cap on it is the fact that the demand side of the market is almost entirely fabrication demand which is price elastic," Dale added.
Analysts said South African gold producers would not be overtly worried about the drop in the gold price.
With the rand weakening against the dollar, South African mines still benefitted from the rand price of gold which was safely above 1,700 rand an ounce.
South Africa's gold industry, the largest in the world but facing declining production and increased costs, has received a boost since the rand shed a quarter of its value since February.
Dale said changes in the rand price were a major concern of the industry. "But more important to the managers of South African gold mines is cost control."
